title: Bulgarian FA criticised for meagre warnings during England Euro 2020 qualifier
text:
The Bulgarian Football Association has been criticised for paying lip service to fears of racial abuse against England players during Monday night’s game after it circulated a leaflet to its fans that only contained feeble warnings against it.

The leaflet, seen by MailOnline, was distributed to supporters clubs of the Bulgarian national team ahead of the match, which has been overshadowed by concerns over the potential racist behaviour of home fans.

England players are threatening to walk off the pitch if it they suffer abuse and the issue has ignited a furious row between football officials of both nations.

The Bulgarian FA have received criticism for its approach to racism in the build up to the game

Listing a series of dos and don’ts to fans, plus other information, only two small bullet points within the leaflet are dedicated to the issue of racial abuse, which has blighted Bulgarian football in recent times at both international and club level.

One reads: ‘Discriminatory abuse, chanting or harassment of any kind is strictly forbidden and will result in arrest and/or ejection from the venue.’

Another states: ‘Swearing or using other profane expressions; gestures and behaviour that might be considered particularly vulgar; expressions and chants that incite hatred on a racial, ethnic or religious basis.’

Other issues, such as bringing bottles into the stadium or travel information, receive more attention.

England stars have threatened to walk off the pitch should they be subjected to racist abuse

The match takes place with a section of the Natsionalen Stadion Vasil Levski closed following incidents of racism during Bulgaria’s previous game against the Czech Republic in June, with Uefa, European football’s governing body ordering that 5,000 of the 46,340 seats be blocked off.

Another 3,000 seats will be closed for the nation’s November encounter against the Czech Republic for incidents of racism during another match against Kosovo.

Pavel Klymenko, Eastern Europe development officer for Fare, an umbrella organisation that fights inequality in football, told MailOnline: ‘The leaflet is just a box ticking exercise. It does not do anything to try and change behaviour and tackle the problem of racism and discrimination by Bulgarian fans.

‘Bulgarian football has been infiltrated by far-right groups who use the stadiums to spread their message of hate. The Bulgarian FA’s response has virtually been non-existent, and you can see that with this leaflet, which is not even being distributed outside the ground prior to the match.

‘We have been trying to work with the Bulgarian FA to do more positive things, but they are not interested. They have not even responded to our letters.’

An estimated 3,400 England fans are expected in Sofia tonight but for once, it is not their behaviour that will be under the spotlight.

Bulgaria boss Krasimir Balakov said this week that English football has a worse racism problem

There have been around a dozen high profile racist incidents within Bulgarian football over the past 18 months with fans abusing black players or unfurling discriminatory or Nazi banners. During last year’s Bulgarian cup final, one young boy was seen giving Nazi salutes while another was displaying a swastika across his chest.

There will be a number of Fare representatives amongst home fans at tonight’s game to monitor and report any incidents of racism.

Along with other campaigners, the organisation has demanded the issuing of banning orders for those found guilty of racist or discriminatory behaviour and a concerted drive by the Bulgarian FA to educate and engage with fans.

Mr Klymenko: ‘We do not even have the provision of banning orders within Bulgarian football. Even when the perpetrators are identified they continue to attend matches. The question is, is the will there within the Bulgarian FA to do anything about racism and discrimination within their game?’

The last time England played in Sofia in 2011, the home nation was sanctioned by UEFA following racist chanting by its fans.

A spokesman for the Bulgarian FA denied Fare’s claims and said that it had been working hard to prevent racist abuse at tonight’s match and overall within its national game.

Hristo Zapryanov told MailOnline that more than 2,000 leaflets had been distributed and that signs will also be in place at the stadium warning spectators of ‘proper conduct.’

Bulgaria FA chief Borislav Mihaylov complained to UEFA about England's growing concerns

He also revealed that all stewards and police have been issued with strict instructions to eject any fans involved in racial or discriminatory behaviour.

Mr Zapryanov added: ‘They will be arrested and dealt with according to Bulgarian law. Everyone is aware of the fact that the England group is extremely sensitive to this issue following problems in previous games.’

The concerns of England players over racism tonight have been heightened by the response of Bulgarian officials, who have either played down the issue or pretended it does not exist within their game.

Ahead of the Euro 2020 qualifier, Bulgaria coach Krasimir Balakov accused English football of having a bigger racism problem than his own country.

He said: ‘In the Bulgarian championship, we have a lot of players of different ethnicities and skin colour. I don't think that we have this big problem like, for example, England do.'

Asked to elaborate, Balakov added: ‘What I meant was that in the Bulgarian championship we've not had such problems while there have been incidents in various levels of English football involving racism, which I consider something normal because it's a big country with a very diverse population.

'But we don't have this problem in Bulgaria, I can assure you of that.’

Borislav Mihaylov, the President of the Bulgarian FA also wrote a letter of complaint to UEFA accusing England of ‘offensive, unjust’ and ‘derogatory’ comments about Bulgarian fans.

This was in response to England manager Gareth Southgate suggesting that he feared the worst in terms of possible racist abuse from the stands in Sofia, while the Chelsea striker Tammy Abraham said the players were prepared to walk off in the face of it.
description: The leaflet was distributed to supporters clubs of the Bulgarian national team ahead of the match, which has been overshadowed by concerns over the potential racist behaviour of home fans.
